title: Woodward Inc (WWD) Q1 2019 Earnings Conference Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

Woodward Inc  (NASDAQ:WWD)Q1 2019 Earnings Conference CallJan. 28, 2019, 4:30 p.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call ParticipantsSee all our earnings call transcripts.



Trending

Guess Who Just Became Amazon's Biggest Shipper
3 Hot Growth Stocks I'd Buy Right Now
3 Reasons People Don't Use Annuities the Way They Were Meant to Be Used


Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Welcome to the Woodward Inc. First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Earnings Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this call is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. Following the presentation, you will be invited to participate in a question-and-answer session.
Joining us today from the company are Mr. Tom Gendron, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mr. Bob Weber, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; and Mr. Don Guzzardo, Vice President of Investor Relations and Treasurer.
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Guzzardo.
Don Guzzardo -- Vice President of Investor Relations and Treasurer
Thank you, Operator. We would like to welcome all of you to Woodward's first quarter fiscal year 2019 earnings call. In today's call, Tom will comment on our markets and related strategies, and then Bob will discuss our financial results as outlined in our earnings release.
At the end of our presentation, we will take questions. For those, who have not seen today's earnings release, you can find it on our website at woodward.com. We have again included some presentation materials to go along with today's call that are also accessible on our website. An audio replay of this call will be available by phone or on our website through February 11, 2019. The phone number for the audio replay is on the press release announcing this call as well as on our website and will be repeated by the operator at the end of the call.
I would like to refer to and highlight our cautionary statement as shown on slide three. As always, elements of this presentation are forward-looking or based on our outlook and assumptions for the global economy and our businesses more specifically. Those elements can and do frequently change. Please consider our comments in light of the risks and uncertainties surrounding those elements, including the risk we identify in our filings.
This quarter Woodward adopted the new accounting standard related to revenue from contracts with customers, commonly referred to as ASC 606. It was effective for October 1st, 2018 and fiscal 2019 first quarter results are presented on that basis. We adopted ASC 606 using the modified retrospective method, under this transition methodology current year financial information including adjusted and organic amounts is presented under ASC 606, while prior year amounts are presented under the previously applicable accounting standard ASC 605.
Overall, at this time, we believe the impact of adoption of ASC 606 will not be material for the full fiscal year 2019. We do believe that there will be quarterly variability in both sales and net earnings resulting from the adoption of ASC 606 as compared to those amounts under ASC 605. It is important to point out that this change will have no impact on cash flow.
To better understand the impacts of ASC 606 on Woodward, we have included additional materials in our press release, and specifically slide eleven of the presentation for this call and the Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q to be filed on or before February 11th, 2019.
In addition, Woodward is providing financial information as reported under US GAAP and on an adjusted and an organic basis. Please refer to our press release and related tables as well as the appendix of today's presentation for the definition of adjusted and organic. We believe this will help in understanding both historical results and future outlooks. We direct your attention to the reconciliations of non US GAAP financial measures which are included in today's slide presentation and our earnings release and related schedules.
Now turning to our results for the quarter. Net sales were $653 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2019 compared to $470 million for the prior year quarter. The first quarter of 2019 included $20 million in net sales related to the adoption of ASC 606. Organic net sales which excludes sales attributable to the L'Orange business were $565 million, an increase of 20% from the prior year quarter.
Net earnings were $49 million or $0.77 per share compared to $18 million or $0.29 per share for the prior year quarter. The first quarter of 2019 included a reduction of $3 million or $0.04 per share related to the adoption of ASC 606. This decrease reflects gross margin differences, net of tax associated with the timing of sales under ASC 606 compared to those under ASC 605.
Adjusted net earnings were $62 million or $0.96 per share compared to net earnings of $33 million or $0.52 per share as adjusted for the prior year quarter. The impact of the adoption of ASC 606 in the first quarter of 2019 was a reduction in adjusted net earnings of $3 million or $0.40 per share.
Net cash generated from operating activities for the first quarter of 2019 was $85 million compared to net cash used in operating activities of $3 million for the first quarter of the prior year. Free cash flow was $53 million for the first quarter of 2019 compared to a free cash outflow of $31 million for the same period of the prior year.
Now I will turn the call over to Tom to comment further on our results, strategies and markets.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Thank you, Don, and good afternoon to those joining us today.
Fiscal 2019 is off to a strong start. In the first quarter, we delivered solid operational performance in our Industrial segment with ongoing strength from L'Orange, while the Aerospace segment continues to perform extremely well.
Before moving into an overview of our first quarter results and market segments, I want to briefly comment on current macroeconomic factors as they relate to Woodward. While uncertainty in the broader economic landscape exists due to the current tariff, ongoing international trade negotiations as well as government shutdowns, our view as we look to the remainder of fiscal year 2019 remains optimistic about our markets, performance and outlook. That being said, we are closely monitoring our end markets and will respond if circumstances change.
Now moving on to our market segments. Our Aerospace segment continues to deliver strong performance driven by healthy global passenger and cargo growth, load factors are at an all time high and a growing number of operators are bringing on new generation aircraft, driving initial provisioning.
Defense budgets continue to support increased military spending. Defense OEM and aftermarket activities saw stronger demand across all platforms with considerable strength in fixed wing and guided weapons.
Now to our Industrial markets. Within power generation, while the industrial turbine market remains uncertain, we appear to have bottomed with inventory stabilizing and our content on newer turbines increasing. In addition, we are seeing robust growth in distributed power for data center applications.
In transportation, natural gas, truck orders and deliveries were strong over the prior year quarter. To date, Chinese government's Blue Sky initiatives on air quality are providing support for higher natural gas truck sales, which are increasing in total and as a percent of total truck sell -- sold.
Oil and gas markets are showing sustained growth in rig counts although, there is heightened volatility in oil prices. Woodward L'Orange continues to enhance our Industrial segment with respect to both sales and earnings. L'Orange contributes positively and have strong offerings that enhance our market positions in power generation, marine transportation and oil and gas.
In summary, we continue to expect strong Aerospace momentum as the historically high backlogs in commercial aircraft support healthy production rates through the next decade. Woodward remains well positioned to further capitalize on the near-term production ramp up along with new opportunities ahead of us. In addition, as the Industrial segment continues to show signs in improvement, supported by strong performance from Woodward L'Orange, we remain confident in our ability to drive increased operational execution and continue delivering superior shareholder value.
Now I'll turn the call over to Bob to discuss the financials.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you, Tom. Before getting into our first quarter results, as Don mentioned earlier, we adopted ASC 606 and I'd like to comment on the more specific -- more significant impacts. Most importantly ASC 606 does not impact cash flow, neither cash from operations nor free cash flow. There will largely be two major components of the change impacting the basic financial statements that we will be pointing out on a regular basis.
First, the timing of revenue recognition on certain products and systems will move forward approximately one quarter, but this will vary.
Second, certain system components provided by our customers at no charge which were previously recorded only as inventory transactions, will now be recorded as revenue with zero margin. This will slightly lower the margin rate but not the nominal amount.
Another important element of the new pronouncement related to disclosures, such as categories of revenue by market segment, which will now be included in our footnotes in the 10-Q beginning with this quarter. Note that this quarter, the impacts of ASC 606 for both sales and earnings primarily related to our Aerospace segment and are insignificant to our Industrial segment.
As Don mentioned, although we expect some quarterly variability going forward, we do not currently anticipate a material impact over the full year from the adoption of ASC 606 as compared to ASC 605.
Now moving ahead to our first quarter performance. Aerospace segment net sales for the first quarter of fiscal 2019 were $393 million compared to $306 million for the first quarter a year ago, a 28% increase. The first quarter of 2019 included an additional $20 million of aerospace segment net sales related to the adoption of ASC 606, largely due to the treatment of customer provided components.
Segment sales were driven by solid growth across commercial and defense OEM and aftermarket programs. Commercial aftermarket sales were up 24% compared to the prior year quarter on a consistent ASC 605 basis.
Based on the new ASC 606 accounting standard, which moved certain repair and overall revenue forward into the current quarter, aftermarket sales were up 34% compared to the prior year quarter. We continue to see favorable fleet dynamics for Woodward, although, we anticipate more moderate growth through the balance of the year due to tougher comps.
Aerospace segment earnings for the first quarter of 2019 was $73 million compared to $45 million for the same quarter last year. Segment earnings for the first quarter of 2019 were reduced by $2 million related to the adoption of ASC 606. Aerospace segment earnings reflected improved leverage on the narrow body production increases, strong aftermarket sales and higher sales across all other platforms. Segment earnings as a percent of segment net sales were 18.5% for the first quarter of 2019.
Under consistent application of ASC 605, segment earnings as a percent of segment net sales would have been 20.1% compared to 14.8% in the same quarter of the prior year.
Turning to Industrial. Industrial segment net sales for the first quarter of fiscal 2019 were $260 million compared to $164 million for the first quarter a year ago. Organic Industrial segment net sales for the first quarter of 2019 were $172 million, which excludes sales of $88 million attributable to Woodward L'Orange.
Industrial segment performance was fueled by solid sales from Woodward L'Orange and improvement in the natural gas truck market in Asia.
Industrial segment earnings for the first quarter of 2019 were $29 million or 11.2% of segment net sales. The growth in segment earnings was driven by the addition of Woodward L'Orange and higher organic sales volume.
Adjusted Industrial segment earnings were $39 million for the first quarter of 2019 or 14.9% of segment sales compared to $20 million or 12% of segment sales in the first quarter a year ago.
At the Woodward level, R&D spending was $39 million for the first quarter of 2019, up from $35 million in the same quarter of the prior year. The increase was primarily due to the inclusion of Woodward L'Orange.
Selling, general and administrative expenses were $52 million in the quarter compared to $46 million in the first quarter of last year. Again, largely due to Woodward L'Orange.
The effective tax rate for the first quarter of 2019 was 20.1% compared to 51.3% in the first quarter of 2018. The prior year period included a onetime expense of $15 million, due to the transition impacts of the change in US tax legislation.
The adjusted effective tax rate was 21% for the first quarter of 2019 compared to 11.9% for the first quarter of the prior year period.
The first quarter tax rate was not materially impacted by the adoption of ASC 606, and we continue to anticipate our fiscal 2019 effective tax rate will be 21%.
Looking at cash flows. Net cash generated from operating activities for the first quarter of 2019 was $85 million compared to net cash used in operating activities of $3 million for the prior year period.
Capital expenditures were 31 million for the first quarter of 2019 compared to $28 million in the prior year period. Free cash flow for the quarter was $53 million compared to a free cash outflow of $31 million for the first quarter of last year. The increase in free cash flow was driven by increased earnings and working capital utilization. We continue to anticipate fiscal year 2019 free cash flow to be approximately $300 million.
Lastly turning to our fiscal 2019 outlook. As we look ahead at the remainder of fiscal 2019, our previously stated outlook remains unchanged. Total net sales are expected to be between $2.65 billion and $2.80 billion for fiscal 2019, with Aerospace sales up approximately 10% and Industrial sales up approximately 30% both as compared to the prior year.
Aerospace segment earnings as a percent of sales are expected to be approximately 20%, adjusted industrial segment earnings as a percent of sales are expected to be approximately 14%. Adjusted earnings per share is expected to be between $4.40 and $4.70 per share based on approximately 65 million fully diluted weighted average shares outstanding.
This concludes our comments on the business and results for the first quarter of fiscal 2019. And operator, we are now ready to open the call to questions.



Related Articles



Woodward Inc (WWD) Q2 2019 Earnings Call Transcript


Woodward Inc (WWD) Q4 2018 Earnings Conference Call Transcript


Why Woodward Stock Dropped 11.5% Today


Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. The question and answer session will begin at this time. (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from Sheila Kahyaoglu from Jefferies. Your line is open.
Sheila Kahyaoglu -- Jefferies -- Analyst
Good afternoon, guys. Thank you, and congratulations on a great quarter.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Thanks. Hi, Sheila.
Sheila Kahyaoglu -- Jefferies -- Analyst
And to you Bob on your retirement.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you, Sheila. So just to focus on(ph)-- no problem -- on commercial aftermarket, I think you said results were up 34% adjusting for the accounting change. I think you had guided to mid-single digit growth for the year. What's coming in better? Can you talk about the dynamics in that business?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. Sheila on the commercial aftermarket, one of the things that we're going to see as we move through the fiscal year is that we've got really strong comps from fiscal year '18. When we look at that, there is -- we had very -- as we highlighted last year, we had very strong initial provisioning sales. And so as we look -- as we move into the rest of the year, we're still a good initial provisioning, but the growth rate won't be there as it was in the previous year. Our MRO activity is still going up pretty consistent with the fleet. And so that's how we get to the single digit. So it's really based on really strong comps from last year.
Sheila Kahyaoglu -- Jefferies -- Analyst
How much of the business is initial provisioning and sort of how should we think about it as selling goes up in rate in the middle of the year?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Look, the majority is still what I'd call I guess legacy traditional aftermarket. There is a significant, but significantly less than half related to initial provisioning.
Sheila Kahyaoglu -- Jefferies -- Analyst
Okay. And then on L'Orange, I thought it came in better than expected. If you could talk about the business dynamics there a little bit please?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. We're very pleased with the integration and the activities going on in L'Orange. The markets are strong and where we're seeing stronger than maybe anticipated sales when we acquired L'Orange is in the oil and gas market. There is really high utilization going on and that's driving aftermarket as well as in marine utilization. So there's not as many new ships being built but we're seeing a lot of utilization. So a lot of this is driving increased aftermarket sales as well as new builds are increasing. So right now, it's good dynamics. We're going to be watching as we go through the year to watch the oil and gas market closely. But overall, it's tracking ahead of plan.
Sheila Kahyaoglu -- Jefferies -- Analyst
Great. Thank you.
Operator
Our next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna of Cowen and Co. Your line is open.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
Hi, thank you guys. And congratulations Bob on your pending retirement.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
So following up on Sheila's question, the year ago comp if I recall on aftermarket Q1 was up 23%. And I'm just curious, so internally when you plan your guidance, were you expecting Q1 of '19 to be as strong as it was in that -- or I'm just trying to gauge how much conservatism is in here, like what can you actually see in the rest of the year?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
On the MRO side, I think we have fairly good forecasting tools. We've discussed in the past, we look at the fleet, we look at engine shop visits, we look at the reliability of our products, the timing of it. So the MRO activity is tracking well to that. So that's gone well. The little more difficult item to track is initial provisioning and the timing of them. We got a good idea, the quantity that we(ph)sell with new operators or new aircraft. But the time is always a little challenging. So we only have maybe two to four months outlook, where we are real solid on that.
We knew we were going to have a decent first quarter maybe a little stronger than we planned, going through the rest of the year, we're looking at deliveries, which operators are taking on. And then from that and the routes, are going to -- they're going to fly what we -- what we forecast for that and that's how we're coming out saying we had really strong IP sales last year, and there's still be strong this year just that we won't have that large growth rate that we did previously.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
And given your visibility, do you expect Q2 to -- I mean it's a plus 29 comp in the prior period. Is it going to be kind of flat to perhaps negative? Or I mean you have two to four months, so presumably, there's something...
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Usually, we don't really forecast on a quarter. But it's
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
Yeah.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
But it's -- as we(ph)through the full remainder of the year, we expect to come down more into the single digit for the full year, right? I think that's -- and some of that's going to be timing, right now, the aftermarket looks good, but like I said, those were really strong IP sales quarters last year as they're second through the fourth.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
Got it. You commented on the L'Orange to $70 million.(ph)We had modeled that something like $75 million of sales each quarter thereabouts was $88 million in Q1. And you talked about some of the reasons, but are these sustainable reasons or do you -- I mean, should we just think that it's going to run rate a much higher level than the $300-ish million that we were thinking previously or how should we think about that?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, it'd be higher than if you model $300 million. But this quarter was a strong quarter for L'Orange. Part of it is, they're coming off of where they used to be the end of their financial year. So it was always a strong quarter for them. So we saw that here as we wrapped up our first quarter. They are tracking ahead of our projections. So we expect a full strong year coming from L'Orange.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen Inc. -- Analyst
Okay. Thank you. I'll get back in queue. Appreciate it.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Okay. Thanks.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski. Your line is open.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Hi, guys. Nice quarter.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Hi, Pete.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Hey, Tom. Just a follow up on that last point of sort of this first quarter traditionally being L'Orange's best quarter. Can you give us a sense timing wise of maybe what is typically(ph)the low quarter for L'Orange?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, we haven't owned them for a full year. But we would look out that, that looks like a strong quarter in the remaining quarters and our outlook are fairly balanced. And like I said, a little stronger than what we had forecast. So positive dynamics going on, and strong execution and the integration is going very well. So we're positive, but I don't think there's going to be like -- there's not going be like a major drop or anything, but probably consistent through the remaining three quarters.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Okay. Just feel like you guys are maybe with L'Orange Industrial from a timing, it's just going to have less seasonality maybe the whole segment, because of L'Orange?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
I think that it will help, definitely, and L'Orange has a very strong aftermarket, and aftermarket helps temper ups and downs in an OEM cycle. So yes, I agree with that Pete.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Okay. And just Tom, I didn't look closely, but it sounds like CAT had a pretty bad number today. Across Industrial, we seeing any kind of signs of weakening in reciprocating engines at all, maybe on the non-L'Orange side?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Now, if you look and you have to dissect CAT a little bit, and in there, I think the energy and transportation segment, take a look at that. I think that was up about 10%, 11%. That's the one that most closely correlates with Woodward.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Okay. Okay.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
And always(ph)said, our sales are mainly to that part of Caterpillar.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Okay. So right now across Industrial and you're not seeing any -- like you said, you're watching oil and gas, but as of right now, you're not really seeing any kind of building headwinds like the tentative macro kind of vibe out there would indicate?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
No. And we -- there's obviously market risk as we highlighted in the prepared comments, but we just kind of recap, we are reciprocating engine business is doing well. We're actually doing well in China. Of course, there's risks with China as everyone knows. Our turbo machinery business has bottomed, and we see that it's starting to turn slowly upwards. So we feel good about that. The one area that's still not performing real well was our renewable business. And outside of that, the segments or the activities within our Industrial business are all moving in a positive direction.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst
Great. Thanks guys.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. Thanks.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse. Your line is open.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Hey, guys.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Hi.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Well, yeah, very nice numbers here. I wanted to ask you though,(ph)when we take L-Orange out of -- the out of the '19 guide, what is the organic growth for the rest of the business? You've just mentioned the renewables there's pressure there. Looks like you were up 5% in the quarter organic Industrial sales, but what's contemplated in this full year guide?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Yeah. It's approximately that. I think we said mid-single sort of at the beginning of the year, and 5%, 6% is very close to what we expect for the full year.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Okay. And then, so I guess we've talked about this on the Aerospace side timing. With all this volume that came through in Q1, and I want to make sure I'm thinking about the margins the right way, you're guiding to think about 20% margin in Aerospace for the year. Should I be looking, I assume at the 606 margin of 18.5% for the quarter as you're guiding to 606 margins, right?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. We are and we're still holding -- even under 606, we're holding 20% for the full year.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
So what's the dynamic in Q1 with all of this heavy volume coming through on the aftermarket side that the margins were a little lower than the full year guide, especially when the sales growth is going to drop off?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Well, it was actually at the 20.1% on a comp basis. So we're going to have this quarterly variability depending upon kind of as I mentioned, the customer provided inventory sort of stuff. So it's 18.5% under 606, but 20.1% under the comp to the prior year. So we still feel we're dead on target if you will. And you're just going to see that non-operational impact of those increased revenues with no margin throughout the year.
Now as Tom said, we believe by the time we get -- these things will flow throughout the quarters. By the time we get to the end of the year, we're confident in being at the 20% under either methodology. And we think a lot of it will flow quarterly and end up being a non-event by the time we get to the end of year.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Okay. I'm probably just getting wrapped up in the two different accounting approaches, but I just want to make sure when I look at slide 12, in red -- the red numbers are the guidance numbers? Or the red numbers conform to the guidance numbers is what I'm trying to say?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
The red number -- so guidance is the same under 606 or 605. The requirement is that we report the current year under 606. So the red numbers there are the reported, they're not the guidance. They're the reported numbers under 606. And so but there is no difference in guidance between the two accounting methodologies. And probably the best slide to take a look at is slide -- page eleven, and there, you can see kind of whether you look at Aerospace segment earnings as a percent or consolidated earnings per share, you can see the deltas between the various methodologies. And it's unfortunate that we have to report under these two methods, but that's the rule. So.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Right. And it's just -- I can see that it's a difference in sales, but I just figured that the guidance would go with the reported. And I'm trying to understand if somehow the profitability in Q1 is below what's expected for the year, despite the fact that Q1 seems to have had the most robust aftermarket performance.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
That is true. On the 606 basis, it's a little bit below what we expect for the full year. Yes.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
And just is there a reason for that?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Non-operational. It's the shift back --
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
That it. So it's just as a percentage of sales, it's just an optics thing.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
That's right, that's right. You look at the dollar amount of earnings, and they are almost identical. So it's just the inclusion of the $20 million in the top line that causes the math to be a little bit lower under the new methodology.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Okay. And then just on the margin increase in industrial attributable to L'Orange. How do we think about the components of that. Can we see that business performing at volume, mix, pricing?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, what I'd say is that it's on increased sales with the margins being pretty consistent, and it's more flow through based on leverage on the volume.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
It's volume driven.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Okay. So and overall just how is pricing across the business?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Pricing is holding. Again as we've highlighted in the past, most of our business is under long-term agreements, so we don't have short-term pricing fluctuations, aftermarket is where there's pricing opportunity, but on the OEM side, it's really fixed.
Robert Spingarn -- Credit Suisse -- Analyst
Okay. Thank you. And congrats Bob.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you.
Operator
Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Glynn of Oppenheimer. Your line is open.
Christopher Glynn -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Thanks. Good afternoon, and good evening. So I had a question about the Industrial margin there, obviously very strong first quarter above your full year guide, and maybe some more restructuring benefits from your initiatives might flow through during the year. Kind of begs the question is the industrial margin guidance given the first quarter, maybe one of the more conservative components of your overall guide?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, right now, we're tracking quite well. I think the thing that we're watching for as we go through the remainder year, there's probably -- there is more uncertainty in our Industrial businesses than there is in our Aerospace business. So as we go forward market, if market -- say market dynamics, market issues stay positively, we probably have an opportunity on the upside, but we're also very cautious about these trade issues, tariff issues, oil and gas prices, there's a number of elements here that could impact our Industrial side, but we're off to a good start and we feel that the past work we did on restructuring the Industrial business, the addition of L-Orange, the -- how well the integration is going that, there could be opportunity, but we have to get to these market uncertainties first.
Christopher Glynn -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Okay. And then a question on 606. Taking your comment that it's not material for the full year, do -- as we think about -- normally your Aerospace margins ramp seasonally through the year along with the volume. So if we think about whatever -- we think about normal seasonality do we reduce the first quarter Aero revs by 20 million and then build the 2Q seasonality from that to get to neutral-ish impact for the year?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Yeah, I'm not -- so the $20 million increase that will sort of continue throughout the year, that's -- the impact of moving things from a timing standpoint will basically kind of level themselves out as we go through the year. So that -- there won't be much impact of this moving forward element. The piece of the puzzle that will continue will be this inclusion of customer inventories in sales. So there will be this dampening of the margin rate from what we've called out as we go through the year, but we don't anticipate it to be significant, and we do anticipate that by as everyone's pointed out, there are upsides to some of our elements here that hopefully will come into play and make that 1.5(ph)delta, a non-event by the time we get to the end of the year.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
I don't know if it's helpful, but we kind of highlighted that in the past and very traditional in our Aerospace business is that you would have used to be called customer furnished equipment that would be provided to us and go into that -- go into our systems. In the old accounting method, that was just an inventory transaction. So we didn't count it in sales, we didn't count it in margins.
So now, it becomes a zero margin sale, which dampens overall segment margin. It's not that huge that'll smooth out along with as Bob said, the timing of sale. So that's why we have confidence, we'll get back to the targeted margins under 606.
Christopher Glynn -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Okay, thanks. And then you gave a lot of helpful color and complexion on the what drives the linearity in the different comps for the Aero aftermarket provisioning. Just wondering about if we do something similar with natural gas bus over in China, how you see the shape of the regulatory regimes and the adoptions? And how that kind of growth should face?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. For all of you that we're at our Investor Day or looked at our investor presentation, we highlighted a little bit about this the Chinese government had this what they're calling the Clear Blue Sky initiatives, and one of those is in some of the major Eastern cities, large cities that they're not going to allow diesel trucks in their city centers. They will allow what they're calling clean energy vehicles and trucks, and so those vehicles that is either natural gas or EV. What we're seeing is that the enforcement of those regulations look like they're going to take hold, that was our biggest concern, because in the past, there's been regulations, but they haven't always been enforced.
So right now, we are seeing a high order book as we move into the year and these regulations kick in, in July. And so at the moment, it's looking positive, but we will want to watch as what happens as that regulation hits in July and its enforcement and that will give us a real picture if the sales continue, and if they do, that's a very positive for Woodward. But we're cautious about that just due to history and timing.
So it's definitely a good opportunity for our Industrial business. So right now, it's looking good. We have a better handle as we get through our second and third quarter.
Christopher Glynn -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Great. Thanks for that.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Thanks.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Michael Ciarmoli of SunTrust. Your line is open.
Wes -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Hey. Good evening guys. It's actually Wes(ph)in for Michael.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Hi, Wes.
Wes -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Just to clarify on the Investor Day, you did mention that you expect for the organic growth rate from Industrial to be 6% for the year. I believe in some earlier -- your earlier remarks, you did mentioned, it's closer to 5% to 6%. I mean is that -- is that the right way to look at it as we progress through the year?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
No. And I think I referred to the 6% as well. The comparison that was used by the question was the 5-ish. And so I've just, we still believe in the 6%. So no change in that, just I was equating it back to the comment that was made.
Wes -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Got it. Thank you. On the turbo machinery, I believe on the last quarter, you did mentioned that you expect the market is bottoming, looking to be flat for the year, although, you're seeing some signs of pickup there, is that -- is that so?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah, it's very slight. But we feel good about that, because it's a change in the curve. And so we're starting to see that.
Wes -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Okay. Can you also just give a little bit more of a details on your facility moves kind of any updates there. And then last still expecting the $20 million in cost synergies from L'Orange integration by 2020?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
So, I'll answer that one first, yes, we're still expecting the synergy savings to come through on that, and we're tracking well and the integration is going well.
Our facility moves are moving forward, and I think you're referring to our Duarte facility for our thrust reverser actuation system business, that's progressing well. And we're standing up the new facility, the moves are all in play -- are all going right now. We're really anticipating getting toward the end of the machine moves, toward the end of March, April.So we're moving pretty well on that.
Wes -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Got it. Thank you, guys.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Welcome.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Chris Howe of Barrington Research. Your line is open.
Chris Howe -- Barrington Research -- Analyst
Good afternoon, everyone. Great quarter.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Thank you.
Chris Howe -- Barrington Research -- Analyst
And congrats Bob on your pending retirement.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you very much.
Chris Howe -- Barrington Research -- Analyst
Just want to dig a little bit more into the macroeconomic environment we're seeing here in China. Just following up on the previous question, you had mentioned that a portion will take hold or has the potential to take hold in July. What's remaining as far as these initiatives and these standards to take place? And hypothetically speaking, if this takes hold in July, how should we think about the acceleration or the cadence toward-- I believe you mentioned before the long term potential for this to hit 20% of Industrial sales under these new emission standards?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, I think the emission standards, first of all, we have been highlighting as the around the natural gas trucks. And I think that like I said, it's moving forward. Well, we are highlighting just I think to be clear was the 20% was to get from the percent of all trucks sold in a year.
Natural gas used to sometimes be between 2%, 5% maybe up 7%. What we're looking at is that it could get up to 20% -plus of the total trucks sold in China. And right now, the order book is kind of showing that, that is happening and it's what we're -- I was talking about earlier with the sustainability of that is really going to be on the enforcement side.
And if it continues, Chinese put in a huge natural gas infrastructure to support natural gas trucks and vehicles. So they have the infrastructure, they're up in their gas reserves and their gas imports. So it looks, it looks positive that way, it's really about enforcement.
The second part of that will go into larger diesel engines and gas engines, where they're going to have further emission requirements. And then anytime you see a higher level of mission requirements, it usually requires more sophisticated fuel injection and control systems. And so that's the positive for our company, and that's what we're talking about. And so the next emissions come on, it should drive further more sophisticated equipment into the larger engine market. So we play in these niche markets and those emission regulations are a positive long term effect as long as the enforcement is there, and that's why -- that's why we always put out a caution on that. But so far, it's looking promising.
Chris Howe -- Barrington Research -- Analyst
That's helpful. And I just had one more last question here. You had mentioned the goal for reducing leverage to 2.0 times, by the end of next year that's still the target. And I guess what I'm getting at is, if the right opportunity came about, would you reduce leverage first before exercising that opportunity a potential acquisition?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Go ahead, Bob.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Just because, -- yes, the 2.0 is still a target for the end of fiscal 2019. So and go ahead, Tom.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. And then part of that target is without potential acquisitions, what we're showing is the ability to pay down that debt quickly and that's what we will do if something did come up we would -- that was very promising and attractive acquisition. We could change that target. But at the moment, we're tracking -- the cash flow is going to be here. We're going to track to delever until we see something that will add shareholder value.
Chris Howe -- Barrington Research -- Analyst
That's all I have for now. Thank you.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Thanks.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you.

Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
We're tracking to their ramp up. So we are on track with that. And yeah, we're -- it flows down to as we usually have about six months ahead as their rate we start to see it. So right now we're tracking to all their requirements.
David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
Okay. On the business jets side things, can you talk about what you're seeing there, obviously, you have much higher content unlike the Global 7500 and the G500 and G600. Can you talk about how those programs are progressing from your side?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Overall, we're seeing some improvement in the entire business jet landscape and as you're highlighting on the new large jets, we have more content. On any individual program right now, we're seeing them try and dig it into production, we're seeing the ramp coming through to us. So they are progressing. I don't know that I can comment on individual one of those in the exact ramps, but it is a positive for the company going forward and it's nice to see them getting on schedule and moving ahead.
David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
The L'Orange accretion for this year, is it still $0.35. It seems like you're hinting that it might be higher than that?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer

David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
Okay. Any sort of number there?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
It's a significant increase. I mean, we've -- as we've mentioned, we've got a lot of uncertainty going through the year, but it could be in the $0.60 range.
David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
Okay. And it sounds like maybe more for me -- maybe more from the margin side from the top line side?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
No. It's both.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Yeah. It'll be both. As Tom said, we've got -- we've got strong utilizations, strong aftermarket. We're getting the leverage on the sales on the volume side. So it's kind of across the board, it's hitting well on all cylinders.
David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
Okay. Last one for me. The backlog amortization with L'Orange that's been excluded or -- from the adjusted numbers. Will that -- will that be finished as of the end of Q2?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
No, roughly at the end of the year. So it's almost tied perfectly with the fiscal year. So that'll drop off by the time we get into the fourth quarter.
David Strauss -- Barclays -- Analyst
Okay. (multiple speakers) All right. Thank you very much.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Sure.

George Godfrey -- CL King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Thank you. I'll add my congratulations on very nice quarter, and Bob, congratulations on retirement very soon.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Thank you.
George Godfrey -- CL King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
You're welcome. The L'Orange business, so I was kind of just touched on that last question that's exactly what I want to talk about. And you said their fiscal year, the December quarter was their year and there's probably a little bit of strength there. But I was thinking maybe you're underplaying your success and ownership that the business is performing, because of Woodward's direction and that this year comes in a little bit better. And I wanted to talk about the synergies maybe on the revenue and cost side that you identified prior to the acquisition being completed and now that you've had ownership. Could you talk about that doing this from memory, I think 30%-plus margins were targeted in L'Orange with the synergies on the cost side, and could you flesh out maybe some of the revenue and cost synergies that you're seeing? Thanks.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. Well, George, on L'Orange, appreciate the comment being under Woodward. The real attractiveness to L'Orange for Woodward was its perfect fit for our company and became an independent fuel injection supplier. So wasn't tied to the engine company anymore. That has opened the doors. We have a lot of discussion dialogue going with potential customers to expand that. Because it's fuel injection, it has a longer new product introduction cycle, but we are seeing great response. We do anticipate that we will drive significant sales synergies over the upcoming years as we get into new programs that I think you're going to see us bring a lot more business.
And on the cost side, we already are rapidly integrating, as you guys remember, we did have a fuel injection business. So we're rapidly integrating the two business together. We are seeing cost synergies, we're seeing opportunities to optimize on our capital equipment. The volumes are going up, which is beyond what we had planned in our business model when we acquired them.
So we're able to leverage our asset base. So that's positive for margins. So that's happening. We've got a great management team and great workforce that came with L'Orange, complementing our team. So that's coming across and overall market reception is good. So it's moving all in the right direction. We're confident in delivering the numbers. And as Bob highlighted earlier, we're actually doing better than what was in our financial model for the acquisition. So tracking really well.
So I guess that's why I leave it, and it's all on track. I think synergies will come through and you'll continue to see good results from that.
George Godfrey -- CL King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Great. Thanks for taking the question, Tom.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President

Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Well, we were looking for somebody that could fill Bob's shoes which is a challenge and Bob -- as you highlighted, Bob has contributed greatly to our company. And so when we're looking, we're looking for a proven financial leader that has driven large comp -- obviously
what you saw from Jack as he's -- he had a decade of experience doing that. We're also looking for somebody to help lead strategy, be the our M&A activity, and so we're looking for somebody that had those skills in their background. We're also looking for somebody that was operationally oriented that could help drive company operations from a financial perspective as well as strategic perspective. And Jack had all those. We also had the real benefit that Jack was on our board for three years, and he has solid understanding of Woodward, he was an excellent board member. His last meeting will be tomorrow, on Wednesday, as we have our board meeting. But he has proven himself on the board and so we are fortunate to bring Jack on and I think he would be a big contributor and help fill that void Bob's leaving.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global -- Analyst

No. There is a impact of the portion that we back out, so that -- it is -- as we've said operationally, it is clearly above, and there is also a partial impact related to the amortization. Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
Okay. And just to be clear, what was -- the change was from what to what on amortization?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
I wouldn't want to break out the total, but the piece that we are adjusting out went down when we got the final numbers related to that. So -- current year impact is more favorable. I'll leave it at that.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
But the more it's driven operationally.
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer

Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst

Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Gautam, they are as anticipated. And we kind of called out, -- yeah you can kind of work out the math -- you'll be able to get from the Q that is approximately $20 million, and $88 million in sales so.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
Okay. Quite Strong?
Robert F. Weber, Jr. -- Vice Chairman, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer
Yeah.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
Fair enough. Thank you. That saves us from doing it. Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Yeah. So mainly, you just have to look at the various items that we highlighted. We feel like we're off to a great start. There is some uncertainty that could impact us on the Industrial markets. If those -- if we have solid market dynamics, we're revisited after the second quarter. But right now, we had a lot of this factored in, and sort of our guidance, we think it's strong guidance and we're extremely confident that we will deliver our numbers this year. And as we move forward and we see things solidify, we'll provide more updated outlook. So that's where -- so things are going good, but we still have these uncertainties that we have to be cautious about.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
And one last one maybe, Tom, in the past you've talked about getting down the learning curve on the new single aisle programs. I'm just curious, what -- how are those doing? Are they actually profitable now on the new OE shipments that you're making? And you don't have to give us a number, but I'm just curious in terms of order of magnitude, how far off the segment average margin are they? And what's the ultimate goal and maturity, like where could they get in terms of margin rate?
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Our depth -- our -- always our intention is to be profitable on OEM sales that's what we always strive for. And in that industry it's a challenge with the way the market is structured, but we think with that we provide more innovative solutions, simpler designs that we're able to achieve that. Right now, that learning curve we've been -- let's do(ph)not say, we've been coming down very rapidly, and I would say as we finish out this year that the new narrow body programs will be running at the -- probably at the average of all of our OEM sales in Aerospace and moving into next year, I'd expect to improve on that.
So we made great progress last year, this year is the big year, and then we'll start smoothing out as we get into fiscal year '20, but it's progressed well.
And that's also how we've been bringing up the segment margins. Yeah, that was one of the things we highlighted, good aftermarket but also improving the margins on our OE side to the ramp up.
Gautam Khanna -- Cowen & Co -- Analyst
Thank you. Appreciate it.
Thomas A. Gendron -- Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President
Okay. You're welcome.
